pullRequest.body:
Given a relation `r` on a type `Î±`, the shortlex order over `r` on lists (first compare by length; if equal, then compare by lexicographic order over `r`) is defined. We prove that this inherits properties from the underlying relation `r` such as trichotomous-icity, asymmetry, order-connectedness. 

Most importantly, `Shortlex r` is well-founded if `r` is well-founded, giving a well-founded order on lists. (Notably, List.Lex is not well-founded). 

---

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:

Deletions:

- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

using the following format:

I noticed that there is something going on with `aux` in a number of the `List.Lex` instances - it got too long to type here so I posted on Zulip: https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/channel/113489-new-members/topic/aux.20appearing.20in.20instance

If you merge master, then the bot will stop posting such silly messages!

The naming largely looks good now, thanks! (or at least, as good as the existing `List.Lex` naming...)

Perhaps @vihdzp has some opinions around the names of the WellFounded stuff, and whether some `instance`s are missing.
Some initial comments, sorry for not having time right now for a more thorough review.

The naming largely looks good now, thanks! (or at least, as good as the existing `List.Lex` naming...)

Perhaps @vihdzp has some opinions around the names of the WellFounded stuff, and whether some `instance`s are missing.
Initial remarks. I expect that there's a lot of golfing that can be done here.

Just nitpicking here but you could write this as `rcases this with h1 | h2 | h3` which saves you the trouble of having to do another `rcases` two lines below. Same goes for line 165 with the extra `rcases` on 171.
oh nice, thanks!

```suggestion
theorem of_length_lt {s t : List Î±} (h : s.length < t.length) : Shortlex r s t :=
```

```suggestion
theorem of_lex {s t : List Î±} (h : s.length = t.length) (h2 : List.Lex r s t) :
```
or `of_length_eq` if you prefer.
I would guess you can make lots of progress here with `simp [shortlex_def]`
`simp [shortlex_def, List.Lex.cons_iff]` does the whole thing, wow!
The "exactly when" in this docstring describes a true and interesting theorem stated with `Iff`, but not the theorem below. Can you add the missing theorem in terms of this one?
oh, you're totally, right, I missed that! it's done now

```suggestion
theorem _root_.List.shortlex_def {s t : List Î±} : Shortlex r s t â
```
Otherwise `shortlex` appears twice in the name.

```suggestion
theorem _root_.List.shortlex_iff_lex {s t : List Î±} (h : s.length = t.length) :
    Shortlex r s t â List.Lex r s t := by
```
The "of" naming is about implication only, not `iff`. You could add `of_length_eq` on the end here if you wanted, but I think it's fine to keep it short as there's no ambiguity.

```suggestion
theorem wf (h : WellFounded r) : WellFounded (Shortlex r) := by
```
since there is no way to infer `h` in your version, and the other two variables are already declared above.

These indents are unusual; better as
```suggestion
    Â· induction a with
      | nil =>
        cases b with
        | nil => right; left; rfl
        | cons head tail =>
          simp only [List.length_nil, List.length_cons, Nat.succ_eq_add_one,
            self_eq_add_left, add_eq_zero, List.length_eq_zero, one_ne_zero, and_false] at h2
```
oh yup, I totally missed updating that when I switched something else
Can you refer to these by their filenames, with `/`s, instead? I don't think docgen really knows how to parse this style of link.
done! if what I've done is correct (merely replacing `.` with `/`), I can also make a small PR updating this in the `List.Lex` file

This seems a bit cleaner (untested)
```suggestion
def Shortlex {Î± : Type*} (r : Î± â Î± â Prop) (a b : List Î±) : Prop :=
  Prod.Lex (Â· < Â·) (List.Lex r) (a.length, a) (b.length, b)
```

Actually, this seems even better. It should allow you to leverage existing instances and theorems on `Prod.Lex` and `InvImage` better:
```lean 4
def Shortlex {Î± : Type*} (r : Î± â Î± â Prop) : List Î± â List Î± â Prop :=
  InvImage (Prod.Lex (Â· < Â·) (List.Lex r)) fun a â¦ (a.length, a)
```
done, thanks!
Very small nit: full sentences like these should probably end in a period.

```suggestion
over a relation `r`  when `s` is smaller than `t` under the lexicographic order over `r` -/
```

You can merge two lines into one:
```suggestion
  rw [Shortlex, h]
```
This should follow from a more general result on the lexicographic order: `(a, b) < (a, c) â b < c`.
This too should also follow from a more general result `(a, b) < (c, d) â a < c â¨ a = c â§ b < d`.

Some slight golfing / formatting
```suggestion
  rw [shortlex_def]
  rintro (h1 | h2)
  Â· simp only [List.length_nil, not_lt_zero'] at h1
  Â· exact List.Lex.not_nil_right _ _ h2.2
```
Does `exact Nat.succ_pos _` work here?
it does, thanks!

For this and the other instances, all of them should be more general theorems about the lexicographic product. Though additionally, do you really need the `IsOrderConnected` property? I've never actually come across that typeclass being used in Mathlib.
I'll work on that! I personally don't need `IsOrderConnected`, but I saw it in the `List.Lex` file and (perhaps wrongly!) assumed it would be a good thing to have

```suggestion
theorem _root_.Acc.shortlex {a : Î±} (n : â) (aca : Acc r a)
```
You can use `suffices` instead to make the proof a bit cleaner.
This theorem should just be a composition of `InvImage.wf` and `WellFounded.prod_lex`.

Hmm, I can't quite get that to work, at least with my naive approach of simply composing the two. (`WellFounded.prod_lex` requires the orders on both elements of the tuple to be well-founded. The lexicographic order on lists is not well-founded). Do you have any further advice to point me along? Thanks!

But the lexicographic order on lists is well-founded! At least, if you define it so that the rightmost entry is the least significant... which is not what Mathlib defines it as.

Alternatively, the lexicographic order on lists is well-founded if you restrict it to lists of a specific length. Which means we could perhaps make use of [`WellFounded.psigma_lex`](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Order/RelClasses.html#WellFounded.psigma_lex)? But that might very well be more trouble than it's worth.

Here's a crazy idea, and feel free to ignore me if you think this will just lead to more trouble. We could define `Shortlex` as
```lean 4
def Shortlex {Î± : Type u} (r : Î± â Î± â Prop) : List Î± â List Î± â Prop :=
  InvImage (PSigma.Lex (Â· < Â·) fun x â¦ Subrel (List.Lex r) fun l â¦ l.length = x)
    fun a â¦ â¨a.length, â¨a, rflâ©â©
```
Separately, we can prove that a well-founded relation induces a well-founded ordering on lists of a given length (i.e. `List.Vector`s). Then, the well-foundedness of the shortlex order just boils down to `InvImage.wf` + `WellFounded.psigma_lex`, hopefully.

Note that if you restrict yourself to bundled `<` relations, then the ugly `PSigma.Lex` thing just becomes `(Â· < Â·)`.

pullRequest.title: feat: shortlex order on lists
